11:13 am
BE11:13am

The Trump administration has issued a licence that will allow US companies to keep doing business with Huawei for the next three months in a bid to contain the fallout from the export restrictions on the Chinese telecoms equipment maker. 

The licence would enable operations to continue for existing Huawei mobile phone users and rural broadband networks in the US, Wilbur Ross, commerce secretary, said in a statement on Monday.

“The temporary general licence grants operators time to make other arrangements and the [commerce] department space to determine the appropriate long term measures for Americans and foreign telecommunications providers that currently rely on Huawei equipment for critical services,” said Mr Ross.

BE11:15am

The Lumentum warning, however, keeps the lid on any enthusiasm for European chip stocks.

BE11:15am

Have Barclays.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

The escalation of the fight between the U.S. and Huawei, has left European semiconductor vendors vulnerable to slowing sales to one of their larger customers, even if the direct impact in most cases is minimal. The direct sales exposure of the likes of STMicro, Infineon, ams and Dialog is, we estimate, in the low-to-mid-single digits of total revenue and for ASML, Aixtron and IQE direct exposure is technically zero but IQE sits one step removed while ASML and Aixtron are a further step back in the supply chain. Despite this, most of our semiconductor names were down between 5-10% yesterday with ams the most heavily hit at -13%. We think this a significant overreaction based on simply the Huawei ban, but our discussions with investors yesterday illuminated a wide range of opinion on what could happen next, with some conclusions more sensational than others, which we think exacerbated yesterday’s stock moves.

Now a temporary 90-day reprieve… What happens next? Is this recent escalation by the U.S. a negotiating tactic? The news overnight that the U.S. Commerce Department intends to grant a number of temporary 90 day exceptions to the blacklist against Huawei could point in this direction. What will be China’s response? We consider a direct attack on Huawei a significant and almost unprecedented escalation. It mirrors the ban placed against shipping to ZTE this time last year, but ZTE had been found to break sanctions and also the ensuing explicit agreements made as part of its reparations (Huawei has not recently been accused of such, although U.S. officials have been attempting to build a case) and ZTE is also smaller and less critical to China’s technology development than Huawei. Any response by China directly against U.S. technology companies could be just as significant given the importance of China, both as a manufacturing partner and as a direct consumer of goods with electronic content. A further escalation risks muddying the waters further for what is a highly complicated and intertwined global supply chain, leading to a potential overall slowing the market.

BE11:16am

In terms of the effect ....

Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:17am

We see European vendors effected in two ways: 1. if they have products containing US-source IP, then those would theoretically be barred from shipment to Huawei even if they are owned by a European company [e.g. ams bought a US company Princeton Optronics and the IP from Princeton is used in lasers they sell to Huawei for 3D sensing]

Grouchmonkey Any discussion on Huawei impact on, e.g. IQE?
11:17 am
BE11:17am

and 2. if critical elements coming from US companies are barred, then Huawei may be unable to finish the manufacturing of the device and therefore any other components would sit in WIP inventory.

BE11:18am

If a bottleneck existed around one critical part, then Huawei is unlikely to continue buying all other parts as normal, as they would simply build inventory and burn cash. If Huawei can’t ship its smartphones or infrastructure, then will other vendors pick up the slack? On handsets, volumes are more fungible and so other vendors are likely to fill the gap; on infrastructure, supply agreements take longer to put into place. To date, we have seen limited shifts of telecom operators sourcing away from Huawei and towards the likes of Ericsson and Nokia, although our conversations indicate many telecom operators are contingency planning.

chopper bear interested to se any pre comment on royal mails results 2mo
BE11:18am

In the meantime, Huawei has between 2 and 4 quarters of component inventory and so we expect limited operational impact in the near-term to Huawei, or its customers, although clearly the public relations issues loom large. We think the bigger impact in the near-term is not for the Chinese customer Huawei but rather the uncertainty for the supply chain, in particular in the U.S., but also in Europe and elsewhere. We see the greatest uncertainty at the direct suppliers, such as STMicro, ams, Infineon and Dialog. Even though IQE doesn’t ship to Huawei, they do ship to chip companies and foundries who supply Huawei, including Lumentum who cut guidance yesterday based on the initial reading of the ban.

IQE PLC (IQE:LSE): Last: 74.70, down 2 (-2.61%), High: 80.00, Low: 72.85, Volume: 1.50m

BE11:19am

Sticking with IQE, here's Canaccord with the readthrough ....

YourGrannyOnBongos Any read-across from Nationwide being less profitable and Tesco throwing the towel in on mortgages?
BE11:19am

IQE indirectly supplies Huawei's smartphone and infrastructure divisions via its US-based wireless customers Qorvo & Skyworks. Based on filings we estimate Huawei is a ~10% blended customer for both currently. While we cannot rule out short-term disruption, IQE's supply relationships with non-US wireless customers should leave the company relatively agnostic to share shifts at the component and OEM level in the mid-to longterm. In Photonics, Lumentum yesterday announced a halt to chip and component shipments to Huawei and lowered its June quarter revenue guidance by 7%. We note the smaller magnitude compared to the Apple production cuts last November when it lowered forecast revenues by ~30%. Huawei is a ~15% customer for Lumentum, mostly for optical transport/ROADM solutions, but we believe IQE's exposure is negligible due to Lumentum using in-sourced wafers for these products. The VCSEL wafer ramp for IQE's largest Photonics customer (we believe Apple) is not affected.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

As the temporary reprieve granted last night shows, the Huawei ban could be lifted or loosened at any time depending on political considerations. However, if it were to stay in place permanently, we could see some potential procrastination around the timing of 5G network deployments and/or smartphone launches. This could temper demand for network infrastructure and 5G smartphones in the next 1-2 years, although ultimately consumer demand for more and faster data will prevail. In addition, Huawei and the wider Chinese Tech ecosystem will likely step up its push to increase supply chain and component in-sourcing with the ultimate goal of achieving 'Chinese Tech independence'. In our view IQE is well-placed to participate in this process and should remain shielded from share shifts higher up the supply chain due to its strong process know-how, technology leadership and performance track record in advanced epiwafer manufacturing.

UDG's interim results reflect good growth in Sharp US, the disposal of Aquilant and the investment in STEM aXcellerate leading to 3% growth in group EBITA. UDG has further enhanced Ashfield with two acquisitions announced this morning deploying $60m upfront with 3-5 year earn outs on Putnam that expands UDG's presence in the important Boston and San Francisco clusters, and £8m on Incisive Health with broadens Ashfield's agency presence. The shares trade on 11x EV/EBITDA, which we continue to regard as fair.

BE11:26am

And Liberum.

BE11:26am

UDG reported half year results this morning. Revenues of $548m, EBIT of $67.4m and adj. EPS of $0.21 was 4% below our forecasts but this was partly driven by FX with the underlying performance broadly as expected. The company has raised guidance to constant currency EPS growth of 5-7pct (4-6pct before) implying a 1pct upgrade. The entirety of this is driven by two just completed acquisitions with the company effectively reiterating its stand alone guidance.

Results slightly below our estimates, in part due to Fx

Group revenues of $548.3m were broadly in line, but EBIT of $67.4m was 6% below our forecasts however part of this was driven by a FX headwind around 2% worse than we had expected.

Ashfield delivered revenues of $380m and EBIT of $47.2m. The under pressure clinical and commercial business delivered underlying growth of 1% which was much better than the expectations for -5% given management's comments at the full year results in November. The Communications and Advisory business was slightly down on an underlying basis however the STEM investments were an 8% headwind here so this business looks to be performing well.

Sharp was a stark contrast, with the US delivering EBIT growth of 22% underlying but the European business providing a $1.6m loss. This is not hugely surprising albeit the US performance was better than we expected, offset by a EU performance that was worse.

Guidance raised, helped by M&A

Management now expect constant currency EPS growth of 5-7%, up from 4-6% previously. The M&A adds 1pct to growth this year which is a little lower than you might expect given the headline forecasts but Putnam is heavily H1 weighted.

In effect management has reiterated it's original guidance and is simply incorporating the M&A benefit

Deals look sensible

Putnam naturally fits within the advisory arm and is well located to build Ashfields US biotech links. Incisive bolsters the European Communications business particularly around market access. UDG is spending $70m upfront with earn outs taking this to c.$100m assuming targets are met. We estimate that it is paying c.8x EV/EBITDA and hence should be value creative for the firm.

Remains good value

At 16x forward earnings for high single digit EPS growth we believe UDG is good value, we reiterate our Buy recommendation.

PBateman made me chuckle
Pharma @VV75 wasn't it $2.40/£ at some points in the 1980s?
red @VV75on a no deal brexit? those levels would be nice, certainly for me, but i can only see this happening for a very short term spike. a trade deal is always the end game, its just a question of how we get there. so you want to be buying historic lows for gbp, if seen of course.

Group adjusted operating profit was $68.3m (Davy: $68.0m). Organic operating
profit increased an estimated 3% (+c.6% ex STEM aXcellerate investment). FX
was a 2% headwind, while net M&A (incl. Aquilant disposal) was broadly neutral.
Ashfield delivered operating profit of $47.2m (Davy: $46.9m), with Ashfield
Communication & Advisory organic operating profit +7% (excluding $2.3m STEM
aXcellerate investment/8% headwind) and Ashfield Commercial & Clinical +1%.
Sharp delivered operating profit of $21.1m (Davy: $21.1m), with strength in Sharp
US +22% organic (Davy: +20%), offsetting a $1.6m operating loss in Sharp
Europe. FCF was very strong with 77% FCF conversion. This was mainly due to
the reversal of delays related to the Oracle implementation last year. We are
forecasting FCF conversion of 62% for FY 19, in-line with the company’s mid-term
target of 60-65%, including elevated capex in Sharp US.

The company also announced two deals this morning. In the advisory space, it is
acquiring US-based Putnam for a total consideration of up to $88.6m (initial
$60m). Focused on product commercialisation (pre-approval), we think Putnam is
an excellent strategic fit with Vynamic and SmartAnalyst. The upfront multiple
equates to an estimated 7.5x EBITA and a 13.3% ROCE. The three- and five-year
earn-outs are based on double-digit profit growth. In the communications space, it
has also acquired UK-based Incisive Health for up to $17.7m ($10.4m upfront).
The company specialises in healthcare policy, public affairs and communication
services. We estimate that the upfront multiple equates to c.5x EBITA.

We have made no change to our underlying assumptions pre-deals and the acquisitions result in 1.7% EPS upgrades to FY 19 and 5.0% upgrades to FY 20 EPS. Our revised EPS forecasts are 49.1c and 54.4c respectively.

We believe the shares have overreacted on the news, with possibly some short term 'event-money’ coming out of the stock, and we would take this as a buying opportunity.

BE11:37am

Mispriced for growth: We continue to believe CCH is undervalued for its
ngrowth advantage to the sector. The shares currently trade in line with the broader European Staples sector (c.23x on 2019E P/E) despite offering organic sales growth that is c.200bps above peers (FY19-21E organic growth +5.8% vs. sector +4.0%).
Further scope for margin expansion: We believe current company guidance of
n+11% comparable EBIT margin is conservative for 2020E. CCH delivered FY18 EBIT margin of +10.3%, a 70bps increase from 2017 (in line with the 5-year average annual margin expansion). We note the current guidance implies c.40bps margin expansion p.a. to 2020. Benchmarking CCH to other Coke bottling peers also suggests there could be scope for over-delivery of CCH’s 2020 target as well as potential for margin expansion beyond 2020 (the average EBIT margin for listed Coke bottlers was c.12.7% in FY18, with best-in-class CCEP at 13.7%). We therefore assume 2020E EBIT margin of 11.3% and 2022E margin of 12.6%.

Irish Fencer Hey folks !
BE11:37am

Balance sheet optionality provides additional upside: CCH’s FY19 net debt to
nEBITDA of 1.1x (on our estimates) remains materially below both the European Staples sector at c.2.0x and the 1.5-2.0x target outlined at its last Investor Day (2016). This is despite the announcement of a special dividend of €2.0 per share at its 1Q19 results, the equivalent of €730mn total consideration (and 6% special dividend yield). We continue to believe the company’s lean balance sheet provides scope for additional upside to the shares from cash use:
Special dividend: If the company chose to lever up to the top of the provided
otarget in 2019, we see scope for the announcement of a second special dividend for a total consideration of c.€1bn (or c.€2.7 per share); this would imply a potential net gain (special dividend yield less EPS dilution) of high single digit.
Generic acquisition: Levering up to the top of the provided target range
oimplies high single digit to low double digit 2020E EPS accretion (assuming different levels of synergies), on our estimates. The company has indicated during its 1Q19 results conference call that while the proposal of a special dividend does increase the company’s FY19 leverage ratio, it does not affect it pursuing M&A.

BE11:41am

FY revenue down 9% on Film, Television & Digital underperformance.

BE11:41am

Stifel:

BE11:41am

21% growth in EBITDA (1% ahead of forecast) came despite headwinds in Film, and some slippage in TV production into FY20. While there was a revenue shortfall in FTD, EBITDA margins, up 5.1pp to 21.0% capture the changing shape of the group, reflecting a higher share of profits from the faster growing Family division (EBITDA +37%), as well as mix effects and restructuring benefits in FTD. There will be changes flowing from revenue-mix and IFRS16 effects (which looks likely to shave off c.3-4% from EPS), but on a pre-IFRS 16 basis, we do not anticipate major changes to EBITDA forecasts overall. ETO starts 2020 with strong momentum in Family, a better production pipeline in FTD and with the bulk of the restructuring work complete. We think the re-engineering of the group's growth and risk profile has yet to be fully reflected in the rating. On a c.13x FY20E EV/EBIT, ETO trades at a 30% discount to the UK media sector and we see headroom towards our 560p DCF-based target price (before Ricky Zoom and a potential refinancing).

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Construction to shrink and no change elsewhere
The latest trading update from management points to stable conditions in Linden and Partnerships combined with the anticipated shrinkage in the Construction business to a base of c£1.3bn of revenue. This shrinkage is resulting in 350 jobs going with the group focusing on Building, Water and Highways end markets. The guidance on exceptional costs of c£40m is unchanged. The cuts are expected to deliver annual savings of £15m from 2021 and make it easier for the group to hit its 2% margin target over the medium term. Linden's sales rates are slightly lower (0.68 vs 0.71) due in part to fewer new sites being released while Partnerships has continued to see strong growth with the pipeline of work continuing to grow. There is no news on either the AWPR or the outstanding claim with the single client. The cash flow and balance sheet are performing as expected, with average net debt unchanged at c£180m. These figures exclude any settlement of the two main claims. We are not making any changes to our forecasts on the back of this update apart from lowering our revenue in Construction. As a result we see no need to change our TP either at this stage. The shares have struggled YTD on the back of the Construction issues and now stand 14% down vs a sector up 14%. As a result the shares now offer material upside to our TP (which assumes a negative £120m value for Construction). Given the ongoing uncertainty about the medium-term profitability of the Construction business we think the market will remain a little wary but we see enough upside to move our recommendation back to Add.

BE11:48am

The idea here is that Galliford's warning in April was a kitchen sink job and today we get the think-of-the-future stuff.

BE11:49am

Liberum:

11:49 am
BE11:49am

oday's trading update follows news on 16 April that the Construction division was expected to take a £30-40m charge this year (to June 2019), and now adds some clarity to this. Within the overall charge – now quantified at approximately £40m - there are two different items: i) write-downs relating to legacy contracts (especially the Queensferry Crossing) and some current projects (smaller in quantum), and ii) a restructuring charge. Restructuring the Construction division will lower divisional revenues from £1.5bn to around £1.3bn and by lowering costs by £15m p.a. will accelerate divisional margin improvement. Management reports that the restructuring charge will cover reducing employment in the division by 350 people. Trading at Linden and Partnerships is in line with previous guidance.

We believe that the stock market should take this statement well because there are no further problems identified with legacy or current construction contracts, and because there is now a visible payback identified with part of the exceptional - the restructuring item. We do not believe that the stock market paid much attention to the restructuring part of the exceptional when it was first announced on 16 April.

red thats 5 yards and a conservative estimate on payout. u will get more of an idea once the recent award gets marked down.
BE11:49am

We see over 60% TSR upside to our target price of 865p (from 970p), which is based on sum-of-the-parts, valuing the housebuilding businesses in line with the smaller peers, taking the average net debt levels and valuing Construction at £70m (2.5x recovered EBIT). At the current share price we find a PER multiple of under 4.0x (cal 2019E) and a 13% dividend yield. The shares trade at under 1x book, which ignores the fact that Partnerships & Regeneration helps give the housebuilding activities a higher than average return on capital employed.

FY18/19E results on May 22nd are expected to reflect a 26% decrease in operating profit to £500m-£530m, driven by deteriorating revenue trends and increasing cost pressures in UKPIL and GLS, likely to persist in FY19/20E. The planned strategy update will likely focus on productivity improvement measures, to mitigate increasing (labour) cost inflation, based on a shorter working week, and likely provide an updated dividend policy, aligned with free cash flow.

For FY19/20E, we estimate adjusted operating profit will be 26% lower at £379m, 20% below consensus £470m, driven by an addressed letter volume decline of 7% and increasing people cost inflation of up to 5.4%, reflecting the full impact from the shorter working week, partly offset by a step-up in cost avoidance to £200m, in line with the recent run-rate.

BE11:58am

Royal Mail's progressive dividend policy is looking challenging, with a dividend of more than £240m, well ahead of estimated FY19/20E free cash flow of £100m (and in line adjusted for timing effects). We had already cut the FY18/19E dividend to £150m (6.3% yield vs. sector 5.2%), in line with projected FY19/20E free cash flow.
